ZPNJEDQQ.title: Inferring global terrestrial carbon fluxes from the synergy of sentinel 3 & 5P with gaussian process hybrid models
ZPNJEDQQ.archive_path: [ARCHIVE] Processes/Evapotranspiration (ET)/GPP, [ARCHIVE] Methodology/Deep Learning (LSTM_CNN)/Gaussian Process Regression, [ARCHIVE] Methodology/Remote Sensing/Satellite Data Fusion
ZPNJEDQQ.idea_path: [IDEA] Data Philosophy/Multi-Source Integration/Satellite Data Synergy, [IDEA] Modeling/Hybrid Modeling (Process+ML)/Data-Driven Workflow

keyword_assessment.current: The ongoing monitoring of terrestrial carbon fluxes (TCF) goes hand in hand with progress in technical capacities, such as the next-generation Earth observation missions of the Copernicus initiative and advanced machine learning algorithms. This study presents a physically-based data-driven workflow for quantifying gross primary productivity (GPP) and net primary productivity (NPP) at a global scale from the synergy of Copernicus’ Sentinel-3 (S3) Ocean and Land Color Instrument (OLCI) and the TROPOspheric Monitoring Instrument (TROPOMI) onboard Sentinel-5 Precursor (S5P), along with meteorological variables from Copernicus ERA5-Land. Specifically, hybrid Gaussian process regression (GPR) retrieval models were created, combining S3-OLCI-derived vegetation products with the TROPOMI solar-induced fluorescence (SIF) product to capture global GPP and NPP. The study highlights the integration of these models into Google Earth Engine (GEE) for efficient processing and mapping.
keyword_assessment.suggested: Terrestrial Carbon Fluxes (TCF), Gross Primary Productivity (GPP), Net Primary Productivity (NPP), Sentinel-3 (S3), Sentinel-5P (S5P), TROPOMI, OLCI, Solar-Induced Fluorescence (SIF), Gaussian Process Regression (GPR), Data Fusion, Remote Sensing, Global Scale, Copernicus, ERA5-Land, Google Earth Engine (GEE)
keyword_assessment.reason: The current 'keywords' are actually a descriptive abstract. The suggested keywords are specific, covering the target variables (TCF, GPP, NPP), the satellite sensors used (Sentinel-3, Sentinel-5P, TROPOMI, OLCI), the key derived product (SIF), the modeling technique (GPR), the data integration approach (Data Fusion, Synergy), the geographic scope (Global Scale), and the processing platform (GEE).

Future research could explore the application of similar data synergy approaches for other critical ecosystem variables, such as evapotranspiration or soil moisture.

The study opens avenues for developing more sophisticated hybrid models that integrate physical processes with advanced machine learning techniques for improved spatio-temporal GPP and NPP monitoring.

NHF5K3FD.title: Beyond the visible: Accounting for ultraviolet and far‐red radiation in vegetation productivity and surface energy budgets
NHF5K3FD.idea_path: [IDEA] Modeling/Physics-Informed AI/Radiative Transfer, [IDEA] Coupling/Energy-Water Nexus/Radiation Impacts

keyword_assessment.current: Photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) typically defined as light within 400–700 nm wavelength range, is crucial for photosynthesis. However, ultraviolet (UV) radiation (280–400 nm) and far-red (FR) radiation (700–750 nm) can also excite photosystems, albeit less efficiently than PAR. This study explores the impacts of explicitly incorporating UV and FR radiation into canopy radiative transfer (RT) and photosynthesis models within a next-generation land surface model (LSM). Using plant measurements under various light sources and intensities, and surface reflections from an eddy-covariance tower, the study validates the improvements. The results suggest that incorporating UV and FR increases mean annual gross primary productivity (GPP) by up to 7.3% and the global GPP by 4.6 PgC per year. Additionally, using PAR as a proxy for UV may overestimate surface albedo, especially in boreal forests. The findings highlight the necessity of implementing hyperspectral or multispectral canopy RT schemes in future vegetation and LSMs.

ZGKA2R8A.title: Estimating global annual gross primary production based on satellite-derived phenology and maximal carbon uptake capacity
ZGKA2R8A.idea_path: [IDEA] Modeling/Hybrid Modeling (Process+ML)/Statistical Phenology Integration, [IDEA] Dynamics/Non-linearity & Complexity/Phenological Drivers

keyword_assessment.current: The high uncertainty regarding global gross primary production (GPP) remains unresolved. This study explored the relationships between phenology, physiology, and annual GPP to provide viable alternatives for accurate estimation. A statistical model of integrated phenology and physiology (SMIPP) was developed using GPP data from 145 FLUXNET sites to estimate the annual GPP for various vegetation types. By employing the SMIPP model driven by satellite-derived datasets of the global carbon uptake period (CUP) and maximal carbon uptake capacity (GPPmax), the global annual GPP was estimated for the period from 2001 to 2018. The results demonstrated that the SMIPP model accurately predicted annual GPP, with relative root mean square error values ranging from 11.20 to 19.29% for forest types and 20.49–35.71% for non-forest types. However, wetlands, shrublands, and evergreen forests exhibited relatively low accuracies. The average, trend, and interannual variation of global GPP during 2001–2018 were 132.6 Pg C yr− 1, 0.25 Pg C yr− 2, and 1.57 Pg C yr− 1, respectively. They were within the ranges estimated in other global GPP products. Sensitivity analysis revealed that GPPmax had comparable effects to CUP in high-latitude regions but significantly greater impacts at the global scale, with sensitivity coefficients of 0.85 ± 0.23 for GPPmax and 0.46 ± 0.28 for CUP. This study provides a simple and practical method for estimating global annual GPP and highlights the influence of GPPmax and CUP on global-scale annual GPP.

The finding that transpiration passively draws energy from the environment for sap ascent provides a new perspective on the land-atmosphere coupling, linking plant physiological processes directly to global energy dynamics.

The research highlights the significant role of CO2 fertilization as a driver of productivity increase, even under rising VPD. Future work could investigate the sustainability of this trend, the potential for 'drought memory' effects, and how different ecosystems respond to these combined pressures. It also suggests exploring the implications for carbon sequestration and climate feedbacks.

The use of SIF as a proxy for GPP, combined with analysis of VPD and CO2, provides a framework for monitoring and understanding vegetation responses to climate change. FG834F6Y.archive_path: [ARCHIVE] Hazards/Drought/DFA / Processes/Vegetation Phenology / Applications/Climate Change Impact
FG834F6Y.idea_path: [IDEA] Dynamics/Non-linearity & Complexity / Dynamics/Drought-Flood Transitions / Mechanism/Feedback Loops & Cascades

keyword_assessment.current: Extreme, dry events have major impacts on vegetation phenology worldwide. However, the differential responses of vegetation phenology to climatic elements during these extreme events remain unclear. We investigated the response of vegetation phenology to climatic factors during extreme events in arid and semi-arid regions of the Chinese Loess Plateau, using the climate water deficit method, to identify extremely dry and wet events. The results revealed that extremely wet events extended the vegetation growth periods in addition to global warming, whereas extremely dry events did not completely counteract this effect. During different extreme events, phenological changes in vegetation on the Loess Plateau were primarily influenced by the interactive effects of climatic factors. During extremely dry events, a 100 mm increase in precipitation advanced the start of the season by 3.0, 9.2, and 16.7 days in forest, shrubland, and grassland, respectively. During extremely wet events, a 1°C rise in temperature delayed the end of the season by 1.6, 0.6, and 3.8 days in forest, shrubland, and grassland, respectively. These findings provide crucial guidance for improving predictions of plant phenology changes under extreme climatic events and unraveling biosphere–atmosphere feedback cycles.
keyword_assessment.suggested: Vegetation Phenology / Extreme Climate Events / Loess Plateau / Differential Response / Precipitation Sensitivity / Temperature Sensitivity / Arid and Semi-arid Regions
keyword_assessment.reason: The current 'keywords' are actually a summary of the abstract. The suggested keywords are more standard and informative, capturing the core subject matter: vegetation phenology, the study region (Loess Plateau), the types of events (extreme), the key finding (differential responses to climatic elements), and specific sensitivities (precipitation, temperature).

Future research could investigate the underlying physiological mechanisms causing these differential responses and how they vary across different vegetation types and regions.

The study quantified the impact of specific amounts of precipitation and temperature changes on phenological shifts. This provides valuable data for refining phenological models and improving drought and flood forecasting systems, especially in arid and semi-arid regions prone to extreme events.

The finding that extremely wet events extend growing periods, even amidst global warming, suggests complex interactions between different climatic drivers. Research could explore how the synergy or antagonism between extreme wetness, dryness, and background warming influences ecosystem dynamics and carbon cycling.

The study highlights how combining different data sources and modeling techniques can reduce uncertainty in ET estimation. related_papers: Paper 0: Stomatal parameters in a changing environment
Paper 2: Dryland evapotranspiration from remote sensing solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence: Constraining an optimal stomatal model within a two-source energy balance model
Paper 3: Reconciling the optimal and empirical approaches to modelling stomatal conductance: RECONCILING OPTIMAL AND EMPIRICAL STOMATAL MODELS
Paper 4: An improved representative of stomatal models for predicting diurnal stomatal conductance at low irradiance and vapor pressure deficit in tropical rainforest trees
innovation_insights: This paper shifts the focus from xylem to soil hydraulics as the primary driver of stomatal closure during drought. This suggests a research direction to quantify the relative contributions of soil moisture stress and xylem embolism in different ecosystems and under varying drought intensities, potentially using coupled soil-plant-atmosphere models with advanced parameterization.

The emphasis on the soil-plant hydraulic continuum opens avenues for investigating how changes in soil properties (e.g., texture, organic matter) and their hydraulic conductivity influence stomatal response to drought. Future studies could explore the 'soil hydraulics thresholds' that trigger significant stomatal closure.

The finding that xylem vulnerability might not be the direct trigger in many cases challenges the conventional understanding. This warrants further investigation into the 'lag' or indirect effects of xylem hydraulic failure on stomatal behavior and the integration of soil moisture dynamics into models predicting drought-induced vegetation stress.

innovation_insights: The integration of Solar-Induced Chlorophyll Fluorescence (SIF) to constrain stomatal conductance (Gc) and subsequently ET is a novel approach. This suggests research into leveraging other remote sensing proxies for plant physiological status (e.g., thermal indices, vegetation indices) in conjunction with SIF to further improve ET estimation and partitioning.

The successful application of the SIF-constrained model in dryland ecosystems highlights opportunities for applying and adapting this methodology to other water-limited regions globally, including arid, semi-arid, and Mediterranean climates, for improved water resource management and drought assessment.

The paper's finding that SIF can effectively partition ET into plant transpiration and soil evaporation opens up research into using SIF for monitoring water use efficiency and hydrological partitioning in complex ecosystems. This could be extended to assess drought impacts on vegetation and soil water dynamics at a larger scale.

innovation_insights: The reconciliation of optimal and empirical stomatal models offers a pathway to develop more robust and theoretically grounded stomatal conductance models. Future work could explore extending this reconciliation to other plant physiological processes or integrating the unified model into larger-scale land surface or ecosystem models with improved parameterization.

The paper's demonstration that the unified model provides theoretical interpretations for parameter values (e.g., g1) suggests a research direction to investigate the functional significance of these parameters across different plant functional types and environmental gradients. This could lead to better predictions of plant adaptation to changing climate.

The ability to correctly capture stomatal responses to rising CO2 levels using this unified model implies potential for its application in assessing plant adaptation strategies to elevated CO2. Further research could focus on how these responses interact with other environmental changes (e.g., temperature, water availability) and their implications for carbon sequestration.

4D2ECM93.title: Global assessment of terrestrial productivity in response to water stress
4D2ECM93.archive_path: [ARCHIVE] Processes/Evapotranspiration (ET), Hazards/Drought, Methodology/Statistical Methods, Applications/Climate Change Impact

keyword_assessment.current: In recent decades, climate warming has led to an increase in atmospheric water demand, a potential reduction in soil moisture, and a rise in the frequency and intensity of droughts. This has intensified the effects of water stress on plants, leading to more vegetated areas experiencing water stress. Soil moisture (SM) and vapor pressure deficit (VPD) are considered the two main factors that exert water stress on vegetation activity and terrestrial productivity, thereby affecting the global carbon cycle. Terrestrial gross primary productivity (GPP) is a key indicator of terrestrial productivity. The eddy covariance method is one essential method for accurately estimating GPP, but it cannot provide continuous spatiotemporal data. Therefore, estimating GPP at regional or global scales relies on ecological process models, light-use efficiency models, statistical models, and machine learning models. However, the differences in the responses of such GPP products to water stress remain unclear, particularly regarding response direction and response speed ('sensitivity'). This study investigates these differences using nine GPP products, analyzing their responses to RSM and VPD. The study reveals consistent patterns in response directions and sensitivities among the products, but also highlights significant regional discrepancies. The findings emphasize the need for employing multiple indicators in related research to ensure robust results and provide an angle for improving GPP estimation by incorporating factors that influence anomalies of terrestrial productivity.
keyword_assessment.suggested: 陆地生产力, 水分胁迫, 土壤湿度, 蒸气压亏缺 (VPD), 全球变化, GPP模型, 响应敏感性, 碳循环, 遥感估算
keyword_assessment.reason: The provided text for keywords is actually the abstract. Actual keywords should be concise terms. The suggested keywords capture the essence of the paper: terrestrial productivity, water stress (driven by SM and VPD), global scale, GPP estimation, and the focus on response sensitivity and model differences.

NHM8HG96.title: Climate warming accelerates carbon release from foliar litter—a global synthesis
NHM8HG96.archive_path: [ARCHIVE] Processes/ET, Hazards/Drought/Flash Drought, Applications/Climate Change Impact
NHM8HG96.idea_path: [IDEA] Mechanism/Feedback Loops & Cascades, Dynamics/Rapid Onset Events, Coupling/Land-Atmosphere Coupling

keyword_assessment.current: With over one-third of terrestrial net primary productivity transferring to the litter layer annually, the carbon release from litter serves as a crucial valve in atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations. However, few quantitative global projections of litter carbon release rate in response to climate change exist. Here, we combined a global foliar litter carbon release dataset (8973 samples) to generate spatially explicit estimates of the response of their residence time (τ) to climate change. Results show a global mean litter carbon release rate (k) of 0.69 year−1 (ranging from 0.09–5.6 year−1). Under future climate scenarios, global mean τ is projected to decrease by a mean of 2.7% (SSP 1–2.6) and 5.9% (SSP 5–8.5) during 2071–2100 period. Locally, the alleviation of temperature and moisture restrictions corresponded to obvious decreases in τ in cold and arid regions, respectively. In contrast, τ in tropical humid broadleaf forests increased by 4.6% under SSP 5–8.5. Our findings highlight the vegetation type as a powerful proxy for explaining global patterns in foliar litter carbon release rates and the role of climate conditions in predicting responses of carbon release to climate change. Our observation-based estimates could refine carbon cycle parameterization, improving projections of carbon cycle–climate feedbacks.
keyword_assessment.suggested: Litter Decomposition, Carbon Release, Climate Warming, Foliar Litter, Residence Time, Global Synthesis, Carbon Cycle Feedbacks, Vegetation Type
keyword_assessment.reason: The current 'keywords' are actually the abstract. They are too long and descriptive for keywords. The suggested keywords are concise and capture the core elements: the process (litter decomposition, carbon release), the driver (climate warming), the material (foliar litter), the key metric (residence time), the scope (global synthesis), and the implications (carbon cycle feedbacks, vegetation type).

innovation_insights: This study highlights a significant discrepancy between tree-ring observations and TBM simulations regarding climate sensitivity in boreal forests, suggesting TBMs may overestimate temperature effects and underestimate drought impacts. This points to a need for improving the parameterization and validation of TBMs using observational data, potentially leading to more reliable projections of forest carbon dynamics under climate change.

Gaps exist in understanding why TBMs overestimate temperature sensitivity and underestimate drought sensitivity. Exploring alternative approaches, perhaps integrating machine learning with process-based models, could also address these limitations.
